member.name: T:DecimalMath.DecimalEx
member.summary: Contains mathematical operations performed in Decimal precision.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Sqrt(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the square root of a given number.
member.param: A non-negative number.
member.remarks: Uses an implementation of the "Babylonian Method". See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methods_of_computing_square_roots#Babylonian_method

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Pow(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns a specified number raised to the specified power.
member.param: A number to be raised to a power.
A number that specifies a power.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ExpBySquaring(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Raises one number to an integral power.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Exp(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns e raised to the specified power.
member.param: A number specifying a power.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Log(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the natural (base e) logarithm of a specified number.
member.param: A number whose logarithm is to be found.
member.remarks: I'm still not satisfied with the speed. I tried several different algorithms that you can find in a historical version of this source file. The one I settled on was the best of mediocrity.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Log(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the logarithm of a specified number in a specified base.
member.param: A number whose logarithm is to be found.
The base of the logarithm.
member.remarks: This is a relatively naive implementation that simply divides the natural log of by the natural log of the base.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Log10(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the base 10 logarithm of a specified number.
member.param: A number whose logarithm is to be found.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Log2(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the base 2 logarithm of a specified number.
member.param: A number whose logarithm is to be found.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Factorial(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the factorial of a number n expressed as n!. Factorial is calculated as follows: n * (n - 1) * (n - 2) * ... * 1
member.param: An integer.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.SolveQuadratic(System.Decimal,System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Uses the quadratic formula to factor and solve the equation ax^2 + bx + c = 0
member.param: The coefficient of x^2.
The coefficient of x.
The constant.
member.remarks: Will return empty results where there is no solution and for complex solutions. See http://www.wikihow.com/Factor-Second-Degree-Polynomials-%28Quadratic-Equations%29

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Floor(System.Decimal,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the floor of a Decimal value at the given number of digits.
member.param: A decimal value.
An integer representing the maximum number of digits after the decimal point to end up with.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Ceiling(System.Decimal,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the ceiling of a Decimal value at the given number of digits.
member.param: A decimal value.
An integer representing the maximum number of digits after the decimal point to end up with.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.GCF(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Calculates the greatest common factor of a and b to the highest level of precision represented by either number.
member.remarks: If either number is not an integer, the factor sought will be at the same precision as the most precise value. For example, 1.2 and 0.42 will yield 0.06.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.GCF(System.Decimal,System.Decimal,System.Decimal[])
member.summary: Gets the greatest common factor of three or more numbers.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.AGMean(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Computes arithmetic-geometric mean which is the convergence of the series of the arithmetic and geometric means and their mean values.
member.param: A number.
A number.
member.remarks: See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic-geometric_mean Originally implemented to try to get a fast approximation of the natural logarithm: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_logarithm#High_precision But it didn't yield a precise enough answer.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Average(System.Decimal[])
member.summary: Calculates the average of the supplied numbers.
member.param: The numbers to average.
member.remarks: Simply uses LINQ's Average function, but switches to a potentially less accurate method of summing each value divided by the number of values.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.GetDecimalPlaces(System.Decimal,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the number of decimal places in a decimal value.
member.remarks: Started with something found here: http://stackoverflow.com/a/6092298/856595

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Remainder(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Gets the remainder of one number divided by another number in such a way as to retain maximum precision.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Pi
member.summary: The pi (π) constant. Pi radians is equivalent to 180 degrees.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.PiHalf
member.summary: π/2 - in radians is equivalent to 90 degrees.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.PiQuarter
member.summary: π/4 - in radians is equivalent to 45 degrees.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.PiTwelfth
member.summary: π/12 - in radians is equivalent to 15 degrees.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.TwoPi
member.summary: 2π - in radians is equivalent to 360 degrees.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.SmallestNonZeroDec
member.summary: Smallest non-zero decimal value.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.E
member.summary: The e constant, also known as "Euler's number" or "Napier's constant"

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Ln10
member.summary: The value of the natural logarithm of 10.

member.name: F:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Ln2
member.summary: The value of the natural logarithm of 2.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ToRad(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Converts degrees to radians. (π radians = 180 degrees)
member.param: The degrees to convert.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ToDeg(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Converts radians to degrees. (π radians = 180 degrees)
member.param: The radians to convert.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.NormalizeAngle(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Normalizes an angle in radians to the 0 to 2Pi interval.
member.param: Angle in radians.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.NormalizeAngleDeg(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Normalizes an angle in degrees to the 0 to 360 degree interval.
member.param: Angle in degrees.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Sin(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the sine of the specified angle.
member.param: An angle, measured in radians.
member.remarks: Uses a Taylor series to calculate sine. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigonometric_functions for details.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Cos(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the cosine of the specified angle.
member.param: An angle, measured in radians.
member.remarks: Uses a Taylor series to calculate sine. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigonometric_functions for details.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.Tan(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the tangent of the specified angle.
member.param: An angle, measured in radians.
member.remarks: Uses a Taylor series to calculate sine. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigonometric_functions for details.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ASin(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose sine is the specified number.
member.param: A number representing a sine, where -1 ≤d≤ 1.
member.remarks: See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverse_trigonometric_function and http://mathworld.wolfram.com/InverseSine.html I originally used the Taylor series for ASin, but it was extremely slow around -1 and 1 (millions of iterations) and still ends up being less accurate than deriving from the ATan function.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ACos(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose cosine is the specified number.
member.param: A number representing a cosine, where -1 ≤d≤ 1.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ATan(System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose tangent is the quotient of two specified numbers.
member.param: A number representing a tangent.
member.remarks: See http://mathworld.wolfram.com/InverseTangent.html for faster converging series from Euler that was used here.

member.name: M:DecimalMath.DecimalEx.ATan2(System.Decimal,System.Decimal)
member.summary: Returns the angle whose tangent is the quotient of two specified numbers.
member.param: The y coordinate of a point.
The x coordinate of a point.
member.returns: An angle, θ, measured in radians, such that -π≤θ≤π, and tan(θ) = y / x, where (x, y) is a point in the Cartesian plane. Observe the following: For (x, y) in quadrant 1, 0 < θ < π/2. For (x, y) in quadrant 2, π/2 < θ ≤ π. For (x, y) in quadrant 3, -π < θ < -π/2. For (x, y) in quadrant 4, -π/2 < θ < 0.
